title: Isolate
text: We want to isolate the variable on one side of the inequality.
speech: We want to isolate the variable on one side of the inequality.
pacedSpeech: We want to isolate the variable on one side of the inequality.

title: Subtraction Property of Inequality
text: To isolate the variable, we can subtract $$14p$$ from both sides of the inequality. This gives us $$9p-14p>14p-18-14p$$.
speech: To isolate the variable, we can subtract  14 p  from both sides of the inequality. This gives us  9 p minus 14 p is greater than 14 p minus 18 minus 14 p .
pacedSpeech: To isolate the variable, we can subtract   14 p
from both sides of the inequality. This gives us   9 p minus 14 p is greater than 14 p minus 18 minus 14 p

title: Simplify
speech: Simplifying the inequality gives us  minus 5 p is greater than negative 18 .
pacedSpeech: Simplifying the inequality gives us   minus 5 p is greater than negative 18

title: Division Property of Inequality
text: Then, we can divide both sides of the inequality by $$-5$$, which gives us $$p$$ on the left hand side and $$\frac{18}{5}$$ on the right hand side.
speech: Then, we can divide both sides of the inequality by  minus, 5 , which gives us  p  on the left hand side and  18 fifths  on the right hand side.
pacedSpeech: Then, we can divide both sides of the inequality by   minus, 5
on the left hand side and   18 fifths

title: Inequality Sign
text: Since we divided by a negative number, the inequality reverses. Hence, we have $$p<\frac{18}{5}$$.
speech: Since we divided by a negative number, the inequality reverses. Hence, we have , p is less than 18 fifths, .
pacedSpeech: Since we divided by a negative number, the inequality reverses. Hence, we have  , p is less than 18 fifths,

title: Interval Notation: Parentheses and Brackets
text: In interval notation, parentheses show that the endpoint of the inequality is not included. For example, the expression "x>3" includes all numbers greater than $$3$$. Since $$3$$ is not included in the solution, the interval notation is $$(3,\infty)$$. Since $$\infty$$ represents "infinity" and is not an actual number, we always put a parenthesis next to $$\infty$$.
speech: In interval notation, parentheses show that the endpoint of the inequality is not included. For example, the expression "x>3" includes all numbers greater than  3 . Since  3  is not included in the solution, the interval notation is , the open interval from 3 to infinity, . Since  infinity  represents "infinity" and is not an actual number, we always put a parenthesis next to  infinity .
